title: Setup Code Quality Tools (Credo, Dialyxir, mix_audit)
description:
## Problem
Spotter has no automated code quality checks. No static analysis, type checking, or dependency vulnerability scanning.

## Solution
Add three standard Elixir quality tools as dev dependencies:
- **Credo** for static code analysis and style checking
- **Dialyxir** for gradual type checking via Dialyzer
- **mix_audit** for dependency vulnerability scanning

Install via mix igniter.install, generate Credo config, and add a unified mix quality alias.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN tools installed WHEN mix quality runs THEN credo, dialyzer, and deps.audit all execute
- GIVEN .credo.exs exists WHEN mix credo runs THEN project style rules are applied
- GIVEN PLT built WHEN mix dialyzer runs THEN type analysis completes using cache

## Rabbit Holes
- Dialyzer PLT building is slow on first run (2+ minutes) — just document, don't optimize
- Credo defaults may be strict — keep defaults, tune later

## No-gos
- No CI/CD integration yet (separate task)
- No custom Credo checks
- No fixing existing code to satisfy checkers

---
Appetite: small. Target: mix.exs, .credo.exs. Architecture: Igniter for dep installation. Sources: mix.exs.

**Output files:**

- .credo.exs — generated Credo configuration

**Technical specs:**

Dependencies to add:
```elixir
{:credo, "~> 1.7", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}
{:dialyxir, "~> 1.4", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}
{:mix_audit, "~> 2.1", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}
```

**Steps:**
1. Run mix igniter.install credo dialyxir mix_audit — adds all three deps
2. Run mix credo gen.config — generates .credo.exs with defaults
3. Verify: mix credo list, mix dialyzer, mix deps.audit

**Source references:**
- mix.exs (lines 27-45): existing deps section

**Edge cases:**
- First mix dialyzer run takes 2-3 min building PLT — expected
- Credo may report style issues in existing code — don't fix in this task
- If igniter can't install, fall back to manual dep entry in mix.exs

**Definition of Done:**
- All three tools installed and runnable
- .credo.exs exists with defaults
- mix credo, mix dialyzer, mix deps.audit all complete

title: Index Claude Code Transcripts into Ash Domain
description:
## Problem
Spotter needs to review Claude Code sessions, but transcripts are raw JSONL files scattered across ~/.claude/projects/. No way to query by project, time, tool usage, or conversation structure. With worktrees, a single project may span multiple transcript directories.

## Solution
Build Spotter.Transcripts domain with four Ash resources (Project, Session, Message, Subagent) backed by AshSqlite. A runtime config file (priv/spotter.toml) defines tracked projects with regex patterns to match transcript directories (handling worktrees). An Oban job reads the config, scans matching directories, parses JSONL, and upserts into SQLite. Expose via AshJsonApi.

Config example (priv/spotter.toml):
  [projects.spotter]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

  [projects.handgemacht]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-handgemacht"

- Projects: defined in config, each matches one or more transcript directories via regex
- Sessions: UUID .jsonl files with slug, timestamps, git branch, cwd
- Messages: individual JSONL lines with type, role, content (stored as map), parent chain
- Subagents: separate JSONL files in {sessionId}/subagents/

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN config has a project with pattern WHEN sync runs THEN only matching directories are scanned
- GIVEN a project matches multiple worktree dirs WHEN synced THEN all sessions belong to one Project
- GIVEN a session has subagent files WHEN sync runs THEN subagents created with correct linkage
- GIVEN JSON API running WHEN GET /api/projects THEN configured project list returned
- GIVEN session exists WHEN GET /api/sessions/:id with include=messages THEN session with messages returned

## Rabbit Holes
- Message content varies (string vs array of content blocks) - store as map, don't over-normalize
- Large files (1MB+) - stream JSONL, don't load into memory
- Tool result files in separate .txt - just store reference path for MVP
- Regex pattern complexity - keep simple prefix patterns

## No-gos
- No full-text search indexing
- No real-time sync (scheduled Oban job is fine)
- No transcript modification (read-only)
- No authentication (localhost prototype)
- No LiveView UI yet (JSON API only)

---
Appetite: reviewed. Target: lib/spotter/transcripts/. Architecture: Ash 3.0, AshSqlite, Oban, AshJsonApi. Sources: config/config.exs, lib/spotter/repo.ex, lib/spotter_web/ash_json_api_router.ex.

title: Create Project Config and Domain + Project Resource
description:
Create the runtime config file, a config reader module, the Spotter.Transcripts domain, and Spotter.Transcripts.Project resource.

**Output files:**
- priv/spotter.toml - runtime config defining tracked projects
- lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex - config reader module
- lib/spotter/transcripts.ex - domain module
- lib/spotter/transcripts/project.ex - resource

**Technical specs:**

Config file (priv/spotter.toml):
  # Transcript source directory
  transcripts_dir = "~/.claude/projects"
  [projects.spotter]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

Config reader (lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex):
- Spotter.Transcripts.Config module
- read!/0 - reads and parses priv/spotter.toml, returns %{transcripts_dir: String.t(), projects: %{name => %{pattern: Regex.t()}}}
- Expand ~ in paths. Compile regex patterns with Regex.compile!/1.
- Add toml hex package to mix.exs dependencies for TOML parsing

Domain (lib/spotter/transcripts.ex): use Ash.Domain, extensions: [AshJsonApi.Domain]. Resources section lists all four resources.

Project resource attributes:
- id (uuid_v7, primary key)
- name (string, required) - config key like "spotter"
- pattern (string, required) - regex pattern string like "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"
- inserted_at / updated_at (create/update timestamps)

Identity: unique_name on name
Relationships: has_many :sessions, Spotter.Transcripts.Session
Data layer: AshSqlite.DataLayer, table "projects", repo Spotter.Repo
Actions: :create, :read (get + list), :update, :destroy

**Source references:** lib/spotter/repo.ex, config/config.exs (Spark formatter section_order)

**Edge cases:**
- TOML parsing: use toml hex package (add to mix.exs deps)
- Path expansion: String.replace(path, "~", System.user_home!())
- Regex patterns should be validated at config read time

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass

title: Create Session Resource
description:
Create Spotter.Transcripts.Session resource for individual Claude Code sessions.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex

**Technical specs:**

Attributes:
- id (uuid_v7, primary key)
- session_id (uuid, required) - Claude session UUID from filename/content
- slug (string, optional) - e.g. "jaunty-bouncing-orbit"
- project_id (uuid, required, FK)
- transcript_dir (string, required) - which transcript directory this came from (e.g. -home-marco-projects-spotter)
- cwd (string, optional)
- git_branch (string, optional)
- version (string, optional) - Claude Code version e.g. "2.1.38"
- started_at / ended_at (utc_datetime_usec, optional)
- schema_version (integer, required, default: 1) - parser-detected format version. Bumped when Claude Code changes JSONL structure.
- message_count (integer, optional)
- inserted_at / updated_at (timestamps)

Identity: unique_session_id on session_id
Relationships: belongs_to :project, has_many :messages, has_many :subagents
Data layer: AshSqlite.DataLayer, table "sessions", repo Spotter.Repo

**Source references:** lib/spotter/transcripts/project.ex, example JSONL fields: sessionId, slug, cwd, gitBranch, version, timestamp

**Edge cases:** Some sessions lack slug. Timestamps are ISO 8601 strings. message_count computed during ingestion. transcript_dir tracks which worktree directory the session came from.

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass

title: Create Message Resource
description:
Create Spotter.Transcripts.Message for individual transcript messages.

**Technical specs:**

Attributes:

- session_id (uuid, required, FK)
- parent_uuid (string, optional) - tree structure reference (not an Ash relationship)

Relationships: belongs_to :session
Data layer: AshSqlite.DataLayer, table "messages", repo Spotter.Repo

**Source references:** lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex. Example: {"uuid":"...","type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":"..."},"timestamp":"..."}. Assistant content can be string or array of {type, text} blocks.

**Edge cases:** Content varies between string and array - store as-is in map. Some messages lack timestamp - skip or nil. Tool result files referenced by path only.

title: Build JSONL Parser Module
description:
Create Spotter.Transcripts.JsonlParser to parse .jsonl transcript files.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex

**Technical specs:**

Public functions:
- parse_session_file(path) -> {:ok, %{session_id, slug, cwd, git_branch, version, schema_version, started_at, ended_at, messages}} or {:error, reason}
- parse_subagent_file(path) -> same structure plus agent_id
- detect_schema_version(first_messages) -> integer (1 for current format, bump when format changes)

Implementation:
- Use File.stream!/1 for line-by-line reading (memory-safe for large files)
- Jason.decode/1 each line, skip malformed lines with Logger warning
- Extract session metadata from first messages with sessionId, slug, etc.
- Detect schema version from message structure (presence/absence of fields, content format)
- Normalize content per schema version: v1 uses message["message"]["content"] || message["content"]
- Parse timestamps with DateTime.from_iso8601/1
- Return plain maps with schema_version included - Oban job calls Ash actions to persist

Schema version detection: Currently only v1 exists. When Claude Code changes format, add a new version detector clause. Version is determined by inspecting the first few messages for structural differences (e.g. new fields, changed content format).

**Source references:** Example files at ~/.claude/projects/-home-marco-projects-spotter/*.jsonl

**Edge cases:** Large files must stream. Some lines have invalid JSON. Content can be string or array. Some messages lack timestamps.

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass

title: Build Transcript Sync Oban Job
description:
Create Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.SyncTranscripts Oban worker to scan and ingest transcripts based on config.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex

**Technical specs:**

use Oban.Worker, queue: :default, max_attempts: 3

Functions:
- sync_all/0 - reads Spotter.Transcripts.Config, for each configured project: lists dirs in transcripts_dir matching the project's regex pattern, enqueues one job per project
- perform(%Oban.Job{args: %{"project_name" => name, "pattern" => pattern}}):
  1. Upsert project via Ash action (match on name identity)
  2. List transcript dirs matching regex in ~/.claude/projects/
  3. For each matching dir, list .jsonl files
  4. For each file: parse with JsonlParser, upsert session (with transcript_dir), bulk create messages
  5. Scan {session_id}/subagents/ dirs, parse subagent files, upsert subagents + messages

Use Ash.bulk_create! for messages (batch 500). Skip already-synced sessions (check existence by session_id).

**Source references:** lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex, lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex, all resource files, config/config.exs (Oban queues)

**Edge cases:** Empty dirs - skip. Duplicate runs - upsert handles it. Large sessions - batch inserts. Missing subagent dirs - check existence.

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass

title: Show session transcripts in dashboard with live sync progress
description:
## Problem
The dashboard only shows tmux panes. There's no way to see synced session transcripts or trigger/monitor a sync. Only the spotter project is configured — aufgabenschmiede worktrees are missing.

## Solution
1. Add aufgabenschmiede project to spotter.toml
2. Add PubSub broadcasts from the sync Oban worker so the dashboard can track progress
3. Add a Session Transcripts section to the dashboard showing projects + sessions from DB, with a Sync button that shows live progress (per-project: syncing/done/error)

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN the app is running WHEN I visit / THEN I see projects and their sessions from the DB
- GIVEN I click Sync WHEN sync runs THEN I see per-project progress updating in real-time (syncing → completed with stats)
- GIVEN sync completes WHEN the dashboard updates THEN session list refreshes with new data
- GIVEN spotter.toml has aufgabenschmiede WHEN sync runs THEN it discovers aufgabenschmiede transcripts

## Rabbit Holes
- Don't paginate sessions yet
- Don't add per-session progress — only per-project

## No-gos
- No session detail view
- No editing project config from UI
- No Oban cron scheduling

---

Target: lib/spotter/, lib/spotter_web/live/, priv/.
Architecture: Ash, Phoenix LiveView, Oban, PubSub.
Sources: lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex, priv/spotter.toml.

Spotter.Transcripts.Project

|> Ash.read!()

State: Add assigns:

- sync_status — map of project name → status atom (:idle | :syncing | :completed | :error)
- sync_stats — map of project name → stats map (dirs_synced, sessions_synced, duration_ms, or error)

Mount: Subscribe to sync:progress. Load projects. Initialize sync_status as %{} and sync_stats as %{}.

Event handlers:
- handle_event("sync_transcripts", ...) — calls SyncTranscripts.sync_all(), sets all known project names to :syncing in sync_status
- handle_info({:sync_started, %{project: name}}, ...) — set project status to :syncing
- handle_info({:sync_completed, data}, ...) — set status to :completed, store stats, reload projects from DB
- handle_info({:sync_error, data}, ...) — set status to :error, store error message

Render: Add section after the header div, before Claude Code Sessions. For each project: show name, session count, sync status indicator. For each session: show slug (fall back to short session_id), git_branch, message_count, and relative time for started_at.

Sync status indicators: :syncing → syncing... with subtle animation, :completed → green checkmark with N dirs and Nms, :error → red X with error message, :idle → nothing shown.

Use inline styles consistent with existing dashboard dark theme.

Relative time helper: Add a private function relative_time/1 that shows Xm ago, Xh ago, Xd ago based on DateTime.diff(DateTime.utc_now(), dt, :second).

title: Terminal scrollback — show full session history in xterm.js
description:
## Problem
When viewing a Claude Code session in Spotter's xterm.js terminal, users can only see the last ~24 lines (the current tmux viewport). The full session history is lost because `tmux capture-pane` is called without scrollback flags, and xterm.js only accumulates content streamed after connection.

## Solution
1. Use `tmux capture-pane -S -` to capture the full scrollback buffer (not just the visible viewport) on initial load
2. Increase xterm.js `scrollback` option to handle large histories (e.g. 10,000 lines)

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a tmux pane with 500+ lines of history WHEN a user opens the pane in Spotter THEN they can scroll up to see all prior output
- GIVEN a tmux pane with ANSI color codes in history WHEN scrollback is captured THEN colors render correctly in xterm.js

## Rabbit Holes
- Very large scrollback buffers (100k+ lines) could cause slow initial load or high memory usage. Start with tmux's default history-limit and revisit if needed.
- Tmux control mode streaming may re-send content that overlaps with the initial capture. Minor visual duplication is acceptable for now.

## No-gos
- Not implementing infinite scroll / lazy loading of history
- Not persisting terminal history to a database
- Not adding search functionality (separate feature)

---
Appetite: reviewed. Target: lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex, assets/js/app.js, lib/spotter_web/channels/terminal_channel.ex. Architecture: Phoenix channels, xterm.js v6, tmux CLI.

title: Capture full tmux scrollback on initial load
description:
Modify `Tmux.capture_pane/1` to capture the full scrollback buffer instead of just the visible viewport.

**Output files**: `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`

**Technical specs**:
Change the `capture_pane` function's tmux command from:
```
["capture-pane", "-t", pane_id, "-p", "-e"]
```
to:
```
["capture-pane", "-t", pane_id, "-p", "-e", "-S", "-"]
```
The `-S -` flag tells tmux to start capture from the beginning of the scrollback buffer (not just the visible area). The `-` value means "start of history".

**Source references**:
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex` lines 52-59 — current `capture_pane/1` implementation

**Edge cases**:
- Empty panes (no scrollback) should still work — `-S -` with no history returns the visible content
- Panes with very large history may return large strings; this is acceptable for now

**Definition of Done**:
- All requirements in the task description are implemented
- `Tmux.capture_pane/1` returns full scrollback history, not just visible viewport
- ANSI escape codes are preserved (the `-e` flag is retained)

title: Increase xterm.js scrollback buffer
description:
Increase the xterm.js terminal scrollback buffer so it can hold the full tmux history received on initial load.

**Output files**: `assets/js/app.js`

**Technical specs**:
Add `scrollback: 10000` to the Terminal constructor options:
```javascript
const term = new Terminal({
  cursorBlink: true,
  fontSize: 14,
  fontFamily: "'JetBrains Mono', 'Fira Code', 'Cascadia Code', monospace",
  scrollback: 10000,
  theme: { ... }
})
```
10,000 lines is sufficient for most Claude Code sessions while keeping memory usage reasonable.

**Source references**:
- `assets/js/app.js` lines 10-24 — current Terminal constructor

**Edge cases**:
- xterm.js handles scrollback gracefully — once the limit is reached, oldest lines are discarded (FIFO)

**Definition of Done**:
- All requirements in the task description are implemented
- xterm.js Terminal is created with `scrollback: 10000`
- User can scroll up through historical content after initial load
